messageBody:
hi!

I'm serialising a class and sending it over a socket to another machine which does not have the classes of the agent. So I'm making two trips, first I'm transferring the jar file containing the classes and I'm using Class.forname("agentclass",true,customjarclassloader) to load the classes.
Then in the next connection I'm transferring the serialised class object to the host. But on reaching the host it gives a ClassNotFoundError when I'm trying to deserialise the object.

What should I do? And how can I implement this serialised object transfer dynamically without first installing the classes on the other host.

Please help me out!


----- Original Message -----
From: Erik Hanson
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, March 05, 2003 9:00 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test error handling?


"Tung Wai Yip" <tungwaiyip@...> wrote:
> Let me give a more concrete example.
>
> try {
> // execute my sql query
> ResultSet rs = sql.executeQuery();
> while (rs.next()) {
> String name = rs.getString("name");
> // do my processing
> }
> sql.close();
> }
> catch (SQLException e) {
> // do my smart error handling here.
> //
> // however this is never called because it is hard to
> // generate a SQLException.
> }

How about extracting your error handling code and testing it by itself:

public class Foo {
public void bar() {
try {
// execute my sql query
ResultSet rs = sql.executeQuery();
while (rs.next()) {
String name = rs.getString("name");
//do my processing
}
sql.close();
}
catch (SQLException e) {
handleSQLException(e);
}
}

void handleSQLException(e) {
//do my smart error handling here.
}
}

public class FooTest extends TestCase {
public void testBar() {
//do whatever tests on bar you want to do
}

public void testHandleSQLException() {
Foo f = new Foo();
f.handleSQLException(newSQLException(...));
//assert that the exeption was handled correctly
}
}
